awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Zero-power Wireless Flame Detector for Ubiquitous Fire Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation – Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project is to advance the development of a disruptive fire monitoring sensor technology that could save thousands of lives and prevent billions of assets loss annually. Currently large-scale wireless fire sensor networks suffer from prohibitive cost associated with ownership, installation and maintenance. Commercially available sensors rely on active electronics to detect and discriminate signal of interest. Therefore, they consume power continuously to monitor the environment even when there is no relevant data to be detected, which results in a short battery lifetime limited to very few months. The proposed wireless flame detectors can be deployed virtually anywhere by dramatically reducing the cost associated with sensor hardware, installation, and maintenance. The completely passive sensing mechanism and wireless connectivity of the proposed technology offer fire protection in environmental conditions considered harsh for conventional electronics (e.g., extreme temperature and limited access to power sources). The project will advance the technology to address the constricted spaces of an aircraft (i.e., the engine or the cargo compartments) where the propagation of fire is significantly hampered, hence restricting the use of the conventional fire detectors. 

The proposed project aims to develop a novel micromechanical flame detector consuming near-zero power in standby until awakened by the specific infrared signature emitted by a flame. The fundamental technical challenge lies in the continuous power consumption of state-of-the-art sensor technologies. The proposed device advances recently developed zero-power digitizing infrared sensors that can selectively harvest the energy from the specific infrared signature emitted from a warm object to operate without using any electrical power. The rigorous fire detector standards require a high level of system robustness and stability against environmental variabilities such as temperature extremes, vibration, and extraneous transients. The proposed project will demonstrate a prototype meeting the national flame detector standards.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We've developed an innovative fire sensor that doesn't need constant power. It's efficient, accurate, and can be a game-changer in keeping places safe from fires. With technology like this, we're one step closer to creating safer environments everywhere.

One of the most profound aspects of our research is its potential to revolutionize fire safety across the globe.

  • Lives and Assets: Our advanced fire monitoring technology is poised to save countless lives and safeguard assets worth billions annually.
  • Cost and Accessibility: By reducing costs related to sensor hardware, installation, and maintenance, our wireless detectors can be used virtually anywhere, providing an inclusive solution to fire safety.
  • Resilience: Tailored for even the harshest conditions, these sensors are ideal for environments with extreme temperatures or limited power sources, offering reliable protection in places where traditional devices might falter.
  • Global Events and Collaboration: Events like the 2019-20 Australian bushfires and the Notre Dame Cathedral fire highlight the urgent need for better fire detection. With our collaboration with a leading fire safety corporation, we aim to address specific challenges in areas like aircraft compartments, ensuring optimal safety in critical spaces.

 Project Outcomes Report 

Cutting-edge sensors lack the intelligence to recognize specific targets. They continuously use power to monitor their surroundings, even when there's no relevant data, limiting their lifespan and increasing the cost of deploying and maintaining extensive sensor networks. A recent breakthrough introduces a new type of zero-power sensors that revolutionize this approach. These sensors, referred to as OFF-but-alert sensors, remain dormant with zero power consumption until activated by a specific physical signature associated with an event of interest. These sensors harness the energy from the relevant signal itself.

In particular, our focus is on IR digitizing sensors that employ plasmonically enhanced micromechanical photoswitches for fire detection. The device selectively harvests the energy contained in the IR signature (such as that of hot CO2) and generates a wake-up signal while disregarding background noise.

Numerous types of fire detectors are currently in use across various settings, ranging from homes and industrial sites to cruise ships and military aircraft. Nonetheless, significant fires continue to occur due to the limitations of these sensors, including their restricted spatial resolution and coverage, resulting in delayed detection. Among the various fire detection technologies available, infrared (IR) flame detectors, which identify the distinctive IR radiation emitted by flames, are particularly appealing for critical applications due to their rapid response compared to alternatives like smoke alarms. However, the primary technical challenge lies in the continuous power consumption of modern fire sensor technologies, making them unsuitable for widespread deployment due to the associated high installation and maintenance costs, such as costly wiring or frequent battery replacements.

Our technology offers a viable solution to this issue by combining cost-effective narrowband IR sensing with zero-standby power usage. In a groundbreaking achievement, we successfully detected a 10 cm butane flame in our laboratory by adjusting the absorption properties to match the IR signature of the flame, specifically the prominent CO2 emissions at approximately 4.3 μm, with a bandwidth of less than 200 nm. Without the use of additional optical components, we measured a detection range of approximately 4.5 meters. This accomplishment translates to a detection threshold equivalent to a detection range of over 70 meters for a 0.09 m2 (1 square foot) heptane flame, which serves as an industrial benchmark for evaluating state-of-the-art commercial IR flame sensors.

The MEMS-based flame detector stands out in the market due to its distinctive blend of plasmonically enhanced absorption, consistent performance across temperatures, and exceptional features. This includes an exceptionally broad field of view, spanning around 120 degrees, highly efficient infrared absorption of over 85%, finely tuned around 4.3 μm, and an extended operating temperature range from -35°C to 85°C. These attributes offer significant advantages compared to any existing technology when it comes to deploying fire detection systems in remote areas for prolonged periods.

In order to maximize the sensitivity to flames while reducing false alarm rates, our flame detectors adopt multi-spectral IR detection schemes. For example, our flame detector, is designed to be sensitive to (1) the IR spectral signatures of hydro-carbon flames (e.g., CO2 emission band around 4.4 μm and H2O around 2.9 μm); and (2) two adjacent spectral bands to detect presence of flame while reducing its false alarm rate. Therefore, we demonstrated plasmonic absorbers targeting four absorption bands with the selected wavelengths (A=2.7 μm, B=3.9 μm, C=4.4 μm D=5.3 μm) to reduce the false alarm rates.

 

[1] Will-Cole, A. R., et al. "Tutorial: Piezoelectric and magnetoelectric N/MEMS—Materials, devices, and applications." Journal of Applied Physics 131.24 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0094364

[2] Calisgan, Sila Deniz, et al. "Temperature-Independent Near-Zero Power Flame Detector Based on MEMS Photoswitch." 2022 Joint Conference of the European Frequency and Time Forum and IEEE International Frequency Control Symposium (EFTF/IFCS). IEEE, 2022.  DOI: 10.1109/EFTF/IFCS54560.2022.9850752
